sentences: Harvard-MIT Division of Health Sciences and Technology
Possible Menstrual Changes During the Perimenopause
[LIST_ITEM] Bleeding for more days than usual
[LIST_ITEM] Bleeding for fewer days than usual Heavier bleeding Lighter bleeding Skipped periods
Genetic factors - e.g. micro deletions X-chromosome, mosaic 45X0/46XX
[LIST_ITEM] e.g. mutation in FSH receptor gene
Life style factors - e.g. cigarette smoking, vegetarian diet
Other factors - e.g. autoimmune diseases (myasthenia gravis) e.g. low body weight
[LIST_ITEM] Onset of menopause determined by the ovary
[LIST_ITEM] Loss of the capacity of the ovary to sustain ovulation
[LIST_ITEM] Nearly complete loss of ovarian follicles
[LIST_ITEM] Minimum 1000 follicles has to be present for ovulation
[LIST_ITEM] Birth - a few million primordial follicles are present
[LIST_ITEM] 500 will reach the stage of a Graafian follicle
[LIST_ITEM] 38 years - disappearance of follicles becomes accelerated
[LIST_ITEM] Mid-thirties - the duration of the menstrual cycle gradually declines
[LIST_ITEM] 4 to 6 years before menopause - women start to notice changes in their menstrual cycle
[LIST_ITEM] Ovulatory cycle remains intact until the mid-forties,
[LIST_ITEM] 5 years before menopause - three-quarters of all women, mean cycle length. Gradually increases from 28 days (range 26 - 32 days) to 60 days (range 35 - >100 days)
[LIST_ITEM] Hormone levels may fluctuate - highly variable between cycles
[LIST_ITEM] Estradiol tends to stay within the normal fertile range (400 - 600 pmol/L)
[LIST_ITEM] Levels below 200 pmol/L at one year after menopause
[LIST_ITEM] Secretion of androgen by the ovary is reduced
[LIST_ITEM] Decline of peripheral androgen levels by 20 - 40 percent
[LIST_ITEM] Early follicular phase FSH levels (cycle day 3 FSH)
[LIST_ITEM] Rise typically 10 years before the menopause
[LIST_ITEM] Ovaries become also progressively less responsive to exogenous gonadotrophins
[LIST_ITEM] Refractory to stimulation with exogenous gonadotrophins
[LIST_ITEM] Products of the ovarian granulosa cells
[LIST_ITEM] Both suppress the pituitary secretion of FSH
[LIST_ITEM] ☐ Sudden sensation of heat rising to the top of one’s body
[H1] May last from 1 month to 7 years.
[LIST_ITEM] ☐ Oophorectomy flashes are more severe and frequent
[LIST_ITEM] ☐ Visible redness of upper chest, neck, face
[LIST_ITEM] ☐ Finger temperature rises p to 6 degrees C.
[LIST_ITEM] ☐ Fatigue, irritability, inability to concentrate, impaired memory
[LIST_ITEM] ☐ Most women have one a day
[LIST_ITEM] ☐ Some have many or a few as one weekly
[LIST_ITEM] ☐ Uniformity of Experience But not Frequency
[LIST_ITEM] May take up to four weeks
[LIST_ITEM] 35%-40% of women ever start conventional ERT
[LIST_ITEM] DXA (Dual Energy X-ray Absorptiometry) measures the spine, hip or total body;
[LIST_ITEM] pDXA (Peripheral Dual Energy X-ray Absorptiometry) measures the wrist, heel or finger;
[LIST_ITEM] SXA (single Energy X-ray Absorptiometry) measures the wrist or heel;
[LIST_ITEM] QUS (Quantitative Ultrasound) uses sound waves to measure density at the heel, shin bone and kneecap.
[LIST_ITEM] QCT (Quantitative Computed Tomography) most commonly used to measure the spine, but can be used at other sites;
[LIST_ITEM] pQCT (Peripheral Quantitative Computed Tomography) measures the wrist;
[LIST_ITEM] RA (Radiographic Absorptiometry) uses an X-ray of the hand and a small metal wedge to calculate bone density;
[LIST_ITEM] DPA (Dual Photon Absorptiometry) measures the spine, hip or total body (used infrequently);
[LIST_ITEM] SPA (Single Photon Absorptiometry) measures the wrist (used infrequently);
[H1] Estrogen Replacement Therapy (ERT) and Hormone Replacement Therapy (HRT).

[LIST_ITEM] Estrogen replacement therapy (ERT) is approved for the prevention and management of osteoporosis. ERT has been shown to reduce bone loss, increase bone density in both the spine and hip, and reduce the risk of hip and spinal fractures in postmenopausal women.
[LIST_ITEM] Alendronate is a medication from the class of drugs called bisphosphonates.
[LIST_ITEM] Risedronate is also from the bisphosphonate family. Taken daily, 5 mg of risedronate slows bone loss, increases bone density and reduces the risk of spine and non-spine fractures.

[LIST_ITEM] Raloxifene, 60 mg a day, is approved for the prevention and treatment of osteoporosis. It is from a new class of drugs called Selective Estrogen Receptor Modulators (SERMs) that prevent bone loss at the spine, hip, and total body. Raloxifene produces increases in bone mass.

[LIST_ITEM] Calcitonin is a naturally occurring hormone involved in calcium regulation and bone metabolism. In women who are at least 5 years beyond menopause, calcitonin slows bone loss, increases spinal bone density,
[LIST_ITEM] DEXA (Dual Energy X-ray Absorptiometry) measures the spine, hip or total body
[LIST_ITEM] SXA (single Energy X-ray Absorptiometry) measures the wrist or heel
[LIST_ITEM] PDXA (Peripheral Dual Energy X-ray Absorptiometry) measures the wrist, heel or finger
[LIST_ITEM] RA (Radiographic Absorptiometry) uses an X-ray of the hand and a small metal wedge to calculate bone density
[LIST_ITEM] DPA (Dual Photon Absorptiometry) measures the spine, hip or total body
[LIST_ITEM] SPA (Single Photon Absorptiometry) measures the wrist
[LIST_ITEM] QCT (Quantitative Computed Tomography) measures spine or hip
[LIST_ITEM] 7.7% of the study participants reported having had cardiovascular disease at enrollment.
[LIST_ITEM] Not intended to measure the effect of HT on vasomotor symptoms
[LIST_ITEM] Women were discouraged from participating in the study if they reported moderate or severe Menopausal symptoms during a 3-month period prior to the study
[LIST_ITEM] Only approximately 500 women aged 50-54 with moderate-to-severe symptoms at study entry were included in the WHI
[LIST_ITEM] Women randomized to the use of estrogen plus progestin were significantly more likely than women randomized to placebo to report a reduction in hot flushes and night sweats.
[LIST_ITEM] Likewise had an improvement in sleep disturbances but no other benefit in terms of the other quality-of-life outcomes reported.
[LIST_ITEM] Continuous conjugated equine estrogen (0.625 mg/d) and medroxyprogesterone acetate (2.5 mg/d) (Prempro®)
[LIST_ITEM] Similar numbers of women in each age category (50-59 years, 60-69 years, and 70-79 years)
[LIST_ITEM] Mean age of study participants was 63 years,
[LIST_ITEM] Most women experience natural menopause around age 50.
[LIST_ITEM] HT is primarily prescribed to women aged 50-59 years,
[LIST_ITEM] 33% of study participants were aged 50-59 years
[LIST_ITEM] Absolute risks for women taking HT starting at age 50 are substantially lower than the comparable risks for women starting use at age 65
[LIST_ITEM] No benefit for the prevention of coronary heart disease
[LIST_ITEM] 29% increased risk of coronary heart disease
[LIST_ITEM] 7 more coronary heart disease events (37 versus 30) per 10,000 women per year, and this risk is cumulative over time
[LIST_ITEM] Confirm an observed trend reported in previous research
[LIST_ITEM] Increased risk of breast cancer with HT use
[LIST_ITEM] 26% increased risk of invasive breast cancer
[LIST_ITEM] 8 additional new cases (38 versus 30) per 10,000 women per year
[LIST_ITEM] Breast cancer takes several years to develop
[LIST_ITEM] Became clinically apparent at four years
[LIST_ITEM] Survival rates are higher in women diagnosed with breast cancer who have taken hormone therapy than those who have not
[LIST_ITEM] 8 additional cases of pulmonary embolism (16 versus 8) per 10,000
[LIST_ITEM] Elevated risk of stroke appears in the second year - continues through year five
[LIST_ITEM] Support previous research - decreased risk of vertebral and other osteoporotic fractures
[LIST_ITEM] Suggest a benefit in the prevention of colorectal cancer
[LIST_ITEM] 6 fewer cases (10 versus 16) per 10,000 women per year
[LIST_ITEM] Subset of 4532 women aged 65 years or older
[LIST_ITEM] Higher incidence of probable dementia - (66% versus 34%)
[LIST_ITEM] Not helpful in preventing mild cognitive impairment
[H1] Recommendations For Hormone Replacement Therapy Use.
[LIST_ITEM] Encouraged to take it for as short a time as needed
[LIST_ITEM] Long-term use should be counseled about the risks and benefits
[LIST_ITEM] Women who want to continue taking HT
[LIST_ITEM] May do so provided they understand the potential risks
HT has been shown to be the most effective treatment for symptomatic relief of vasomotor symptoms including hot flashes
Nonhormonal alternatives such as selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors, may be helpful for this indication
Combined continuous estrogen and progestin therapy is no longer recommended for the prevention of cardiovascular disease
Alternatives for improved cardiovascular health, including lifestyle modifications such as exercise, smoking cessation, and weight loss, should be encouraged for all women.
The use of cholesterol-lowering medications such as statins and the need for treatment of hypertension should be evaluated for each individual patient.
